DOC.HEAD: Inventor Has Ideas, Lacks Buyers
DOC.TEXT: Jack Scherbak said he always figured if you built a better roach killer, the world would beat a path to your door. He claims he has. They haven't. A self-proclaimed jack-of-all-trades, he admits to only a slight frustration in his latest attempt to crack the corporate marketplace with a new idea. ``Some people have money and no ideas. Other people have ideas, and no money,'' he said in an interview. ``I'm in the latter category.'' Scherbak, 49, who also works as a carpenter and plays classical guitar at nightclubs and restaurants, majored in physics and math for one year at the University of Nebraska-Lincoln. But literature finally won out over math. ``Science has always been restricted,'' he said last week. ``In a sense, it's just like the guitar. You have to practice to be able to express your emotion.'' Inspired by beat poet Jack Kerouac, Scherbak left college and hit the road. He joined the Army and was a medic in Texas, then took art and sculpture classes in New York City. Several years ago he submitted a plan to the Nebraska Energy Office to fill discarded aluminum cans with popped pocorn and build insulating panels, walls, roofs, ``even a whole house,'' he said. ``They said it was a novel idea, but no loan company would give a person a loan to build with something so unconventional,'' he said. Earlier this year, Scherbak confronted a real and present problem: roaches under the kitchen sink. Commercial roach traps didn't work, he said. Sprays were toxic and he didn't want to endanger his family's health. So, he began mixing common household ingredients until he found a nontoxic combination that worked. He won't say what's in it because it's not patented yet. He put it in a spray can labeled ``ZEZ, the world's first non-toxic roach spray.'' He carries the can along with a plastic gallon jug full of live roaches and a large metal kettle for demonstrations. After dumping four roaches into the kettle, he sprayed them with ZEZ. As they died, he sprayed the product into his eyes and mouth. ``The roaches are dead but I'm OK,'' he said. He's not bashful in attempts to market the stuff. Last month, he wrote to the entertainment director of ``The Tonight Show,'' saying he'd like to meet Nebraska native Johnny Carson and demonstrate his product on the television show. ``There's still no word from Hollywood, but at least we don't have roaches under our sink anymore,'' he said.
